TEXT: The applicant is a NORP national , born in DATE and living in GPE , GPE . She is represented before the ORG by Mr PERSON , a lawyer practising in GPE , GPE . The respondent Government are represented by their Agent , Mr PERSON , ORG .
The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .

After an interview held in DATE the applicant got a job as a telephone operator in a taxi company . She started the job on DATE , but not until DATE was she provided with a written contract in which it was stated inter alia :
“ The terms of the employment will be regulated by the LAW on salaried employees ( GPE ) and a collective agreement entered into with ORG ( Handels- og PERSON ) . ”

The above collective agreement was entered into in DATE between , on the CARDINAL side , the employer and ORG ( ORG ) and , on the other side , ORG , henceforth called ORG and its local office in the area where the employer company is situated . According to the agreement the employer would only employ telephone operators and office workers who were members of GPE .
At DATE the employer became aware that the applicant was not a member of ORG , but of another trade union , and on DATE the applicant was dismissed because she refused to become a member of ORG .

The applicant instituted proceedings before ORG ( ORG ) against the employer , ORG , ORG and its local office claiming compensation and requesting that they be ordered to recognise that her dismissal and the above closed shop agreement was unlawful . She alleged that since she was not aware of this agreement at the time of her employment the dismissal was a violation of section CARDINAL , subsection CARDINAL of LAW against Dismissal due to ORG of DATE , as amended on CARDINAL DATE ( Lov om beskyttelse mod afskedigelse på grund af foreningsforhold ) . Moreover , she alleged that the closed shop agreement itself violated LAW as it allegedly allows an employer to require that an employee must be a member of an association or a specific association in order to obtain employment . By judgment of CARDINAL DATE ORG granted the applicant compensation in the amount of MONEY ( DKK ) as it found it established that the applicant was not aware of the agreement at the time of her employment . Therefore , there had been an infringement of section CARDINAL , subsection CARDINAL of LAW against Dismissal due to ORG of DATE . However , as to closed shop agreements in general the court stated inter alia as follows :

“ LAW secures the classical freedom of assembly and association including the right to form and join trade unions . By the British Rail judgment ( the PERSON , PERSON and PERSON v. GPE judgment , Series A no . DATE ) it was established that in certain circumstances LAW also secures the negative right to freedom of association . This judgment resulted in the ORG ’s passing of LAW against Dismissal due to ORG .

Following the passing of this Act the Court of Human Rights has pronounced other judgments concerning the extent of LAW . The applicant has submitted these judgments , notably the GPE v. GPE judgment of DATE in support of her claim that section CARDINAL , subsection CARDINAL and subsection CARDINAL of GPE against Dismissal due to ORG are at variance with LAW .

However , these last judgments have not resulted in any NORP Government Bills with a view to amend LAW against Dismissal due to ORG . On the contrary , PERSON recently ... declared in ORG that it was the ORG ’s view that closed shop agreements do not infringe human rights and that GPE does comply with its international obligations .

LAW of DATE ( No . CARDINAL of DATE ) incorporated ORG into NORP law . According to the preparatory notes the incorporation did not intend to change the existing balance between ORG and the NORP courts . Therefore , the ORG still has a considerable discretion when laying down NORP law .

Thus , since LAW against Dismissal due to ORG was passed in order to comply with LAW , and since the exceptions mentioned in LAW , subsection CARDINAL of the Act are formulated very precisely , and since a decision that sets aside or limits the existing possibility to enter into closed shop agreements would have far - reaching consequences for the NORP labour market , the High Court finds it appropriate to leave it to the legislature to decide whether the previous case - law from ORG does require an amendment of LAW against Dismissal due to ORG . ”
On appeal , ORG ( Højesteret ) on DATE upheld ORG judgment . In its reasoning ORG stated inter alia as follows :

“ Act no . CARDINAL of DATE on Protection against Dismissal due to ORG was passed , notably in order to comply with the negative right to freedom of association to the extent an obligation thereto could be established according to the interpretation of LAW given by ORG , PERSON and PERSON v. GPE judgment Series A no . CARDINAL ( ORG ) .

As stated in ORG judgment of CARDINAL DATE ( concerning application no . PERSON and PERSON v. GPE ) and of DATE ( concerning application no . CARDINAL GPE v. GPE ) the latest judgments from ORG give no reason to asses the lawfulness of closed shop agreements and their consequences any differently than what appears from the ORG judgment . In ORG view neither does the PERSON and others v. GPE [ ORG ] , ORG . ORG , CARDINAL and CARDINAL , ORG CARDINAL-III ) . ”

Thus , as mentioned above , in CARDINAL other cases , ORG decided by judgments of DATE and DATE , respectively , on the lawfulness of closed shop agreements in relation to LAW against Dismissal due to ORG of DATE and in relation to LAW and found that closed shop agreements as such are not contrary to LAW as the provision has been interpreted by the ORG .
Section CARDINAL of LAW ( PERSON ) provides :
CARDINAL . ORG shall , without previous permission , be free to form associations for any lawful purpose . ORG

CARDINAL . ORG Associations employing violence , or aiming at the attainment of their object by violence , by instigation to violence , or by similar punishable influence on persons holding other views , shall be dissolved by a court judgment .
CARDINAL . No association shall be dissolved by any government measure ; but an association may be temporarily prohibited , provided that immediate proceedings be taken for its dissolution .
CARDINAL . Cases relating to the dissolution of political associations may , without special permission , be brought before ORG ( NORP øverste domstol ) .
CARDINAL . The legal effects of the dissolution shall be determined by statute .

LAW against Dismissal due to ORG of DATE ( which was passed as a direct result of the ORG ’s ruling in DATE in the PERSON , PERSON and PERSON v. GPE judgment , Series A no . CARDINAL ) , amended by Act no . CARDINAL of CARDINAL DATE , reads in as far as relevant :
Section CARDINAL
ORG An employer may not dismiss an employee on the grounds that he or she is a member of an association or of a certain association .
Section CARDINAL
CARDINAL . An employer may not dismiss an employee on the grounds that he or she is not a member of an association or of a certain association

CARDINAL . Subsection CARDINAL does not apply if the employee , prior to recruitment , knew that the employer made membership of an association or of a specific association a condition for being employed with the enterprise .

CARDINAL . Subsection CARDINAL is furthermore not applicable when the employee , who is a member of an association , subsequent to the employment is informed that membership is a condition for continued employment with the enterprise
Section CARDINAL

Sections CARDINAL and CARDINAL of the Act do not apply to employees who are employed by employers whose business specifically aims at furthering a political , ideological , religious or cultural purpose and the membership of the person concerned must be considered of importance for the business .
Section CARDINAL

Where an employee is dismissed contrary to the provisions of this LAW , the dismissal must be overruled and the employment continued or restored , if so claimed . However , this does not apply to employees in the private sector if , in special cases and following a balancing of the interest of the parties , it is found obviously unreasonable to claim continuation or restoration of the employment .
Section CARDINAL.a
CARDINAL . Where an employee is dismissed contrary to the provisions of this LAW without the dismissal being overruled , the employer shall pay compensation .
. If the employment has lasted for DATE , such compensation may not be CARDINAL months’ salary or wages .
Section CARDINAL.b
CARDINAL . Cases under this LAW must be processed as quickly as possible .

CARDINAL . During the hearing of a case concerning dismissal , the court may order that the dismissal will not become effective until the case has been finally decided by a judgment . The judgment may stipulate that the dismissal will not be stayed in case of an appeal .

The Act on Private Contributions to Political Parties and Disclosure of the Accounts of Political Parties , No . CARDINAL of CARDINAL DATE ( Lov om private bidrag til politiske partier og offentliggørelse af politiske partiers regnskaber ) as amended by LAW . CARDINAL of DATE reads in as far as relevant :
Section CARDINAL

ORG federations , trade unions and other trade associations whose main objectives are to attend to the economic interests of the trade group to which their members belong shall ensure that any financial contribution to political parties or for party political purposes in general collected as part of partnership fees are collected on a voluntary basis for the individual member .
Section CARDINAL

CARDINAL . A member , who wants to be exempt from payment of contributions to political parties or for political purposes in general as part of the membership fees shall submit a written declaration to this effect .

CARDINAL . Once a year the association shall forward to its members a form containing the wording of such declaration . Publishing the form in a ORG journal or a similar publication can fulfil such obligation . The declaration must have the following wording : “ I want to be exempt from payment of contributions to political parties or for party political purposes in general as part of my membership fees ”

CARDINAL . The declaration must be forwarded to the auditor of the association . This must appear from the form referred to in subsection QUANTITY hereof . Declarations forwarded to association offices by the members must be re - forwarded to the auditor immediately . The Minister of ORG may lay down further provisions on the layout of the form and ORG treatment of declarations received .
CARDINAL . Information on the persons who are exempt from payment of contributions or who have made a request to this effect may not be subject to any unauthorised disclosure .
Below is a general description of the background of closed shop agreements in the NORP labour market .

The struggle at DATE between on the CARDINAL side employees and their unions ( notably what is DATE called the ORG , i.e. ORG ) and on the other side the employers and their federations ( mainly the central organisation DA , i.e. ORG ) resulted in the so - called DATE Agreement from DATE between the ORG and the ORG . The ORG laid down CARDINAL major principles :
CARDINAL . the right of employees to organise in trade unions ;
CARDINAL . the right of the employers to manage and control work ;
CARDINAL . the right to industrial actions ( strike , boycott and lockout ) to obtain
e.g. a collective agreement ;
CARDINAL . the embargo on industrial action , which means that no strikes are
lawful during the term of a collective agreement ;
CARDINAL . the establishment of a special arbitration tribunal to deal with all
violations of LAW .

The DATE Agreement is unique in that it has formed the basis of all subsequent general agreements between social partners . By tradition the NORP legislature plays a minor role as regards governing wages , salaries and employment conditions . Therefore , only to a limited extent does the NORP labour marked have legislation , which does not emanate from ORG , e.g. LAW ( GPE ) and LAW ( Ferieloven ) . Accordingly , rights imposed by statute in other countries have in GPE been obtained by agreements between the labour market partners . It is thus characteristic of NORP law that the relationship between employers and employees is basically governed by a combination of agreements ( collective and individuals ) , labour law principles and general statutes and rules laid down in pursuance of statutes . CARDINAL per cent of all employees in GPE are union members .

From figures provided by ORG ( PERSON ) and ORG ( Beskæftigelsesministeriet ) , in DATE the NORP workforce consisted of CARDINAL persons ( inclusive unemployed ) . Thereof CARDINAL were employed within the private sector and CARDINAL within the public sector .
The Government estimates that MONEY of all employees are comprised by collective agreements . The applicant disagrees with this estimation .

The institution of closed shop agreements is of long standing in GPE . Typically a closed shop agreement states that an employer has undertaken only to hire and employ members of the trade union that is party to the collective agreement concluded by the employer . Closed shop agreements are unlawful in the public sector labour market and they are not concluded in the part of the private sector labour market , which is comprised by the general agreement between the DA and the LOC , because ORG considers the use of closed shop provisions as an interference with the ORG managerial right . Thus , closed shop agreements are mainly of importance in collective agreements concluded with unorganised employers .

The precise number of employees covered by closed shop agreements is unknown . However , from figures provided by ORG and ORG the Government estimate that CARDINAL wages earners are affected in some way by closed shop agreements , thereby affecting CARDINAL per cent of all NORP employees on the labour market . The applicant submits that this estimation probably is somewhat below the actual figure .

After the election in GPE on DATE the new Government decided to procure a report on closed shop agreements . The report was submitted in DATE ( PERSON . DATE , GPE om eksklusivbestemmelser ) and recommended that closed shop agreement be prohibited .
The preparatory notes to LAW
The preparatory notes to LAW DATE of the Conference of Senior Officials , Collected Edition of the “ ORG ” , vol . PERSON , p. CARDINAL ) state inter alia :

“ On account of the difficulties raised by the ‘ closed shop system’ in certain countries , the Conference in this connection considered it undesirable to introduce into the Convention a rule under which ‘ no one may be compelled to belong to an association’ which features in [ LAW ] of LAW ” .
The European Social Charter DATE
LAW provides for the following “ right to organise ” :

“ With a view to ensuring or promoting the freedom of workers and employers to form local , national or international organisations for the protection of their economic and social interests and to join those organisations , the Contracting Parties undertake that national law shall not be such as to impair , nor shall it be so applied as to impair , this freedom . The extent to which the guarantees provided for in this Article shall apply to the police shall be determined by national laws or regulations . The principle governing the application to the members of the armed forces of these guarantees and the extent to which they shall apply to persons in this category shall equally be determined by national laws or regulations . ”

In its Conclusions ORG and GPE ORG found that LAW against Dismissal due to ORG infringes on LAW , in so far as an employee can be dismissed if the employee prior to recruitment knew that membership of a certain union was a condition for being employed with the enterprise ( section CARDINAL , subsections CARDINAL and CARDINAL of the Act ) . On this basis ORG in its CARDINAL’th ( DATE ) and CARDINAL’th report ( DATE ) recommended to ORG that a recommendation in this respect be adopted with regard to GPE . On DATE at the CARDINAL meeting of ORG , lacking the majority required , the proposal for the said recommendation was not adopted .
In its Conclusions XVI-CARDINAL ORG stated inter alia :
“ The situation in GPE is not in conformity with LAW for the following reasons :
Closed shop clauses are permitted in national law , as illustrated by the decisions of ORG summarised in the report . Clauses or practices of this kind violate the right to freedom of association ”

Subsequently , in DATE ORG informed ORG of the European Social Charter of its intentions to introduce a bill prohibiting closed shop agreements . ORG therefore decided to await the next assessment by ORG .
ORG

Conventions no . CARDINAL and CARDINAL under ORG protects inter alia the positive aspects of the freedom of association . As regards the issue of closed shop agreements ORG considers this as a national matter .
